repository.orgName: Staats- und Universitätsbibliothek Hamburg Carl von Ossietzky

msContents.summary: This is the commentary on the Chāndogyopaniṣad by Raṅgarāmānuja. Thick dark brown wooden guard folio. Number 56 is written in roman in pink chalk. First blank folio with title: Chāndogyabhāṣyam rāmānujīyam.

msItem.title: Prakāśa (Chāndogyabhāṣya)
msItem.author: Raṅgarāmānuja
msItem.incipit:
8 syllables broken as the folio corner is damaged śaśivarṇam caturbhujaṃ prasannavadanaṃ dhyāyet sarvavighnopaśāntaye | atasīgucchasacchāyamañcitoraḥsthalaṃ śriyā || añjanācalaśṛṅgāram añjalir mama
gāhatām || vyāsaṃ lakṣmaṇayogīndraṃ praṇamyānyāngurūnapi chandogyopaniṣadvyākhyāṃ karavāṇi yathāmati || brahmavidyopayīkaṃ karmmāṅgaviṣayamādyaupāsanamupa
diśyate || oṃ ityetadakṣaram
msItem.explicit: muktañca vaśarīrādvimuktaḥ | kṛtam nityam bhagavaślokam kṛtā tā sat avu |

support.p: Thick dark brown wooden guard folio.

extent.measure: 2 guard folio, 1 blank and 178 written folio

supportDesc.foliation: Tamil numerals in the left margin on the recto of each folio.
supportDesc.condition: Some worm holes and the folios are broken around the corners and margins.

additions.desc: First blank folio with title: Chāndogyabhāṣyam rāmānujīyam
(gap of two letters due to broken margin) gyopaniṣad is written in the left margin on 1v.
śubham astu hariḥ oṃ is written in the left margin on 1v.

listBibl.bibl: Ānandāśrama Sanskrit granthāvaliḥ granthāṅkaḥ 63 śrīraṅgarāmānujaviracitaprakāśopetā cāndogyopaniṣat etat pustakaṃ ve. śā. rā rā Gokhale ityupāhvair Gaṇeśaśāstribhiḥ saṃśodhitam ānandāśramamudraṇālaye mudritaṃ Pune 1910

encodingDesc.p: Space added to separate words. Question mark is used for doubtful reading. Brackets are used for inferred reading.

revisionDesc.change:
In the summary, are Roman numerals Roman numerals (XII) or Western numerals (12)? In the foliation, are the Tamil numerals meant to be on the recto or on the verso as stated? Is this the commentary called chandogyopaniṣadbhāṣya or prakāśa? Could you take a look at the edits in the bibliography? (śanskrit > Sanskrit, etc.) In the incipit, is the śaśivarṇam meant to be anusvara?
Kind wishes, Riccardo
